preface.title: Preface
purposeParagraphs:
Based on the information you've provided —
                    blood test results, your medical history, your family history, or other indicators —
                    it makes sense to initiate a program that addresses the factors that drive cognitive impairment.
                    Symptoms of cognitive impairment may include the inability to focus,
                    make decisions, find words, or remember names, faces, or places.
                    40% of all adults over the age of 65 have some memory loss — so you are not alone.
                    However, there is hope for those concerned about experiencing some memory loss.

This report contains an assessment of where you stand now and
                    has been created specifically for you.
preface.statisticCallout:
Based on the information you've provided —
                    blood test results, your medical history, your family history, or other indicators —
                    it makes sense to initiate a program that addresses the factors that drive cognitive impairment.
                    Symptoms of cognitive impairment may include the inability to focus,
                    make decisions, find words, or remember names, faces, or places.
                    40% of all adults over the age of 65 have some memory loss — so you are not alone.
                    However, there is hope for those concerned about experiencing some memory loss.
aboutParagraphs:
Multiple medical issues often contribute to memory loss.
                    The
                    care plan
                    uses information such as your
                    lab results, medical history, diet, and lifestyle to identify issues
                    that may be causing your memory concerns.
                    Your medical information is combined with medical research to create a
                    customized treatment plan designed to address your specific issues.
                    Your plan may help slow memory decline and stabilize memory function
                    associated with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) or
                    early dementia [ 1-4 ] .

intro: Let's get started on a path to lasting brain health!

As noted above, many medical factors can often contribute to memory loss,
                    including your lab results, medical history, medications, diet, and lifestyle.
                    Here is what this report covers:

steps.title: Overview of Risk Factors
steps.description:
It gives a brief overview of the risk factors that are within an optimal range, as well as the
                        factors that are not in a good range and may be contributing to cognitive impairment or memory
                        loss.

steps.title: Personalized Action Plan
steps.description: Next, it presents a personalized action plan for reducing the impact of these risk factors.

steps.title: In-Depth Insights
steps.description:
Lastly, for those interested in the details, it describes how the risk factors related to your
                        blood tests can contribute to cognitive impairment or memory loss.

healthStatusSections.title: Optimal
healthStatusSections.description:
These factors are within optimal range,
                            unlikely to be contributing to cognitive impairment or memory loss

healthStatusSections.title: Caution
healthStatusSections.description:
These factors may be contributing somewhat to
                            cognitive impairment or memory loss

healthStatusSections.title: At Risk
healthStatusSections.description:
These factors are likely to be significantly
                            contributing to cognitive impairment or memory loss

healthStatusSections.title: Unknown
healthStatusSections.description:
There is not enough data to determine if this
                            factor is contributing to cognitive impairment

actionPlan.title: Your Action Plan - Start Today!
intro:
The previous sections identified risk factors that may be contributing to cognitive impairment or
                    memory loss. This section is your action plan for reducing the impact of some of those risk factors,
                    broken up into these areas:

The more of this action plan you follow, the better your likelihood of positively impacting your
                    brain health.

medications.medication: methylcobalamin 1 mg in 1 mL intramuscular injection
medications.guidance: Repeat as needed during the first 2 weeks, if vitamin B12 level remains below 200 pg/mL.

Take on an empty stomach, 1/2 to 1 hour before breakfast. Avoid taking supplements or
                            medications that contain calcium, magnesium, or zinc (such as antacids) for 4 hours
                            afterwards.
Discuss appropriateness & eligibility for lecanemab with your doctor.

supplements.title: Supplements and How To Take Them
intro:
Five
                        new recommended supplements are shown below in prioritized order
Start at the top and work down the list

Slowly ramp up the number of new supplements;
                        consider starting with just the first one
                        — vitamin D3/K2 —
                        and watching carefully for any side effects

Five
                        days later, if okay, add the next

                        recommended supplement

entries.action:
Vitamin K2 enhances absorption of
                                cholecalciferol.

meds.guidance:
Best taken at the largest meal of the day, and along with calcium and magnesium (if
                                those are among current medications).

Best taken either 30 minutes before, or two hours after, eating to avoid competing with
                                protein for absorption.

reasoning.action: ApoE gene indicates increased risk of Alzheimer's disease.

meds.guidance: Best taken with a fatty meal, to increase absorption.
Best taken on an empty stomach: 1 hour before or 2 hours after eating.
Ramp up slowly: 1 capsule/day the 1st week; then 2 capsules/day.

lifestyle.title: Your Lifestyle
lifestyle.intro:
You've gotten a start with any new medications and supplements.
                                Great job!
                                Continue to take them on their recommended schedule.
                                Let's improve on
                                your quality of sleep,
                                moving your body,
                                keeping stress low,
                                maintaining great hygiene,
                                and
                                exercising your brain.
                                You can do all these steps together if you want
                                or
                                add them at your own pace. [ 5-7 ]

recommendations.task: Find at least 30 minutes of relaxing activity each day.
instructions: Spend some time with people you enjoy and those who support you

Include walks, music, meditation, naps, yoga,
                                            or whatever provides relaxation, at least once a day
The importance of a positive attitude cannot be overstated

People who are often stressed are more likely
                                            to experience brain shrinkage and increased production of the amyloid beta
                                            peptide

Some stresses are unavoidable,
                                            but low stress levels are important for delaying or avoiding symptom onset

Seek treatment for
                                            Obstructive sleep apnea, which can reduce the quality of your sleep

One
                                            medication may be disrupting your sleep

Focus on earlier bedtime (the time at which you go to bed),
                                            not wake time (not how late you sleep)

recommendations.task:
Fast every night for at least 12 hours,
                                            between the last food in the evening and the first in the morning.
                                            Begin the fasting at least 3 hours before bedtime.
instructions:
Autophagy is a process by which cells break down and
                                            recycle their own damaged or unnecessary components

Autophagy may assist in clearing the accumulation of beta-amyloid,
                                            a protein that is a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease,
                                            as well as clear the accumulation of tau,
                                            another protein associated with neurodegenerative diseases

Occasional daytime fasts are also helpful,
                                            such as fasting for a day (or most of a day) every few months

recommendations.task: 3 to 4 times a week, for 30 to 45 minutes each time (with doctor's approval)
instructions: Mix both cardio & resistance (weight) training each week

recommendations.task:
Push your mental abilities hard!
                                            Give your brain a tough workout every day.
instructions:
Examples:
                                            become a tutor,
                                            learn a new language or new field,
                                            take dance lessons & dance often,
                                            learn to play a musical instrument,
                                            memorize poems,
                                            even do math problems in your head

[ 8 ] Good social activities include bridge & chess,
                                            and walking & talking with friends

recommendations.header_intro:
Dietary patterns characterized by higher intake of
                                        vegetables,
                                        fruits,
                                        fish,
                                        nuts, and
                                        legumes,
                                        and lower intake of
                                        meats,
                                        high fat dairy, and
                                        sweets are related to lower odds of cognitive decline.
                                        The place to start is with the eating guidelines in the well-studied MIND diet.
recommendations.mind_diet_intro:
The Mediterranean-DASH Intervention for Neurogenerative Delay (MIND) diet is
                                            a hybrid of two successful eating plans, but with modifications to reflect
                                            the scientific literature on foods and nutrients that are specific to brain
                                            health. It emphasizes ten foods that have been shown to slow cognitive
                                            decline in clinical studies. It also names five food groups to avoid, due to
                                            their adverse effects on the brain.
recommendations.recommended_instructions: Focus on choosing from among these ten recommended food groups.

entries.foodGroup: Green leafy vegetables (like spinach or salad greens)

entries.frequency: Use these as your main cooking oils

recommendations.discouraged_instructions:
Foods to limit:
                                        the MIND diet discourages eating from these five unhealthy food groups.

entries.foodGroup: Red meat (like beef, lamb, or pork)

entries.frequency: Avoid more than one serving a week
Avoid more than one serving weekly, if at all

summary.title: Dietary Overview
summary.warning:
Three potential dietary issues were identified in the most
                                                            recent blood serum results

consumption.advice:
Further discussion and follow-up with a dietitian or nutritional
                                            professional is recommended.
consumption.title: Dietary consumption

entries.note:
Slow caffeine metabolism
                                                                is indicated by the CYP1A2 genes,
                                                                so drink no more than two cups of coffee each day (200mg
                                                                of caffeine) and finish them by noon.
                                                                Although there is caffeine in green tea,
                                                                it contains less caffeine than black tea,
                                                                and in turn black tea has less caffeine than coffee.

                                                                Wait two hours after taking the medication
                                                                levothyroxine
                                                                before drinking any coffee.

currentMedication.title: Current Medications
currentMedication.intro:
These are the medications you told us about.
                                                    These include your prescriptions, vitamins, supplements,
                                                    over-the-counter drugs,
                                                    regular injections, eye drops, and so on.
                                                    Let us know if there's anything you'd like to add, change, or
                                                    remove.

medications.dosageDetails: 0.01%, 3 gtts / both ears / every other day

cognitiveFunction.title: Factors Related to Cognitive Decline
cognitiveFunction.intro:
This section describes how certain risk factors identified in your
                                                    blood tests may contribute
                                                    to cognitive impairment or memory loss
                                                    —
                                                    and gives you targets to aim for, working with your doctor.
                                                    Discuss other risk factors,
                                                    such as those related to medications and genetics,
                                                    thoroughly with your doctor.

entries.description:
Chronic conditions: hypertension; osteoarthritis; likely
                                                            obesity; probable poor sleep quality; possible depression;
                                                            possible kidney disease; possible lipid disorders; and
                                                            possible thrombocytopenia
Having multiple
                                                                chronic conditions is associated with a greater risk of
                                                                mild cognitive impairment and dementia.

This level of homocysteine is above target.
                                                                Elevated levels are associated with atrophy of a key
                                                                area in the brain for memory, called the hippocampus.
                                                                High homocysteine can also facilitate a buildup of
                                                                undesirable components in the brain, known as
                                                                beta-amyloid plaques and tau proteins. Without adequate
                                                                intake of the right B vitamins, homocysteine can
                                                                accumulate and contribute to memory problems.

This very low vitamin B12 level may be linked
                                                                to the break down of myelin (the protective sheath
                                                                around nerve cells), brain cell atrophy, increased
                                                                inflammation, and high homocysteine levels. All of these
                                                                can contribute to memory problems. Further evaluation as
                                                                to its cause is recommended.

Elevated insulin levels, including the high
                                                                insulin associated with type 2 diabetes, are associated
                                                                with key drivers of cognitive decline: brain
                                                                inflammation, amyloid plaques, and tau tangles. In
                                                                particular, high insulin increases beta-amyloid
                                                                accumulation. This insulin level, far above target, may
                                                                significantly accelerate the progression of cognitive
                                                                decline, so further evaluation is recommended.

The formula known as the Homeostatic Model
                                                                Assessment for Insulin Resistance (HOMA-IR) estimates
                                                                insulin resistance using your fasting glucose and
                                                                insulin levels. The high level seen here can occur when
                                                                your body cannot readily absorb glucose from the
                                                                bloodstream. The body thus needs higher levels of
                                                                insulin to help glucose enter cells. Insulin resistance
                                                                may contribute to fatigue, and can lead to brain
                                                                inflammation, amyloid plaques, and tau tangles, so
                                                                further evaluation is recommended.

A level of 100 to 125 mg/dL indicates
                                                                impaired fasting glucose, a type of prediabetes. This
                                                                increases the risk of developing type 2 diabetes.
                                                                Insulin resistance can lead to brain inflammation,
                                                                amyloid plaques, and tau tangles — each a driver
                                                                of cognitive decline.

This value for total cholesterol is
                                                                considered far above target, which can lead to vascular
                                                                disease. Factors associated with vascular disease are
                                                                associated with cognitive decline in aging, and they
                                                                also include previous heart attacks, narrowing of the
                                                                cerebral arteries, hypertension, and diabetes.

This level of LDL (known as the bad
                                                                cholesterol) is above target. Increased LDL cholesterol
                                                                levels are linked to increased likelihood of developing
                                                                beta-amyloid plaques, an indicator of Alzheimer's
                                                                disease. Additionally, high LDL can lead to
                                                                atherosclerosis.

Thyroid hormone balance is important for
                                                                synaptic balance and cognitive optimization.
                                                                Hypothyroidism (as indicated by analyzing TSH, T3 and T4
                                                                levels) are known to cause cognitive impairment.
                                                                Clinical guidelines recommend screening for thyroid
                                                                abnormalities in those showing symptoms of cognitive
                                                                impairment.

Thyroid hormone balance is important for
                                                                synaptic balance and cognitive optimization. The thyroid
                                                                produces “inactive” thyroxine (T4), which is
                                                                converted into “active” triiodothyronine
                                                                (T3). T3 helps regulate the body's temperature,
                                                                metabolism, and heart rate. The T3 that doesn't
                                                                otherwise bind to protein is called free T3. Higher
                                                                levels of free T3 are desirable to prevent cognitive
                                                                decline.

Within the brain, zinc plays a key role in
                                                                reducing inflammation. Brain inflammation is often seen
                                                                in those with cognitive decline, and may directly impact
                                                                its progression. This low level may also be an indicator
                                                                of metal toxicity, such as elevated levels of mercury or
                                                                lead in the blood.

This ratio between copper and zinc is far
                                                                above target. High copper is linked to a decline of
                                                                cognitive abilities, whereas zinc is neuroprotective and
                                                                has been shown to reduce inflammation and to lower
                                                                copper levels. The relationship between these two is out
                                                                of balance; a target ratio is 1.0 (that is,
                                                                approximately one-to-one), each with a value near
                                                                100.

Those with low vitamin D levels may lose
                                                                memory and thinking abilities faster than those with
                                                                optimal levels. Vitamin D affects bone metabolism,
                                                                reduces inflammation, appears to inhibit the development
                                                                of Alzheimer's disease, and affects cardiovascular
                                                                disease.

This value for estimated glomerular
                                                                filtration rate (eGFR) is low, indicating possible
                                                                chronic kidney disease (CKD). eGFR signals how well
                                                                kidneys are filtering blood and getting rid of waste. A
                                                                normal reading for eGFR ranges from 90 to 130 ml/min,
                                                                with no protein in the urine. A reading of 60 to 89 may
                                                                indicate a mild decrease in kidney function. Values
                                                                under 60 imply stage 3 CKD.

Creatinine clearance (CrCl) is a measure of
                                                                the flow rate through the kidneys, and that rate is
                                                                below target. This indicates possible stage 3 chronic
                                                                kidney disease (CKD). The Gault-Cockcroft equation is
                                                                used to calculate creatinine clearance. It takes four
                                                                values: 1) a person's blood creatinine level, 2)
                                                                their age, 3) their gender, and 4) their body weight
                                                                (unlike eGFR, where weight is not a component).
                                                                Creatinine clearance provides a repeatable measure of
                                                                renal filtering capability which takes all of these
                                                                factors into account.

Sleep apnea
Sleep apnea accelerates cognitive
                                                                decline in two ways: it deprives the brain of necessary
                                                                oxygen, and it reduces the amount and quality of sleep.
                                                                Urgently assure it is addressed thoroughly.

Very low exercise duration (how long each session): 5
                                                            minutes/week
